speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, proposals by the Ontario government would give counties and regions authority over woodlots greater than 2.5 acres and other municipalities the power to control individual shade trees, windbreaks and fence rows.
These proposed changes could have a serious impact on private landowners' rights and should be of concern to anyone who has a tree growing on his or her property.
Ontario is pushing responsibility on to municipalities while at the same time allowing clear cutting on its own Crown lands. My constituents are tired of too much government and this proposed legislation promises to be a nightmare of permits, regulation, and enforcement; all to the detriment of the taxpayer.
Canadians love the privileges that come with freedom, peace, private property and the pursuit of the work ethic.
At this sensitive time in our country's history, I urge members of Parliament to work to find ways to support and encourage law abiding, environmentally conscious private citizens rather than targeting them with restrictive and expensive laws which have not worked in eastern Europe or elsewhere.

Mr. Speaker, once again the Conservative government is interfering with multicultural organizations instead of co-operating with them.

The minister is trying to undermine the World Sikh Organization by funding to the tune of $130,000 the National Alliance of Canadian Sikhs.
The World Sikh Organization has represented Sikhs without any grants or subsidies from the government, yet the minister has the nerve to proclaim the alliance as the principal organization representing Sikhs.
It is time the government stopped interfering in the internal matters of ethnocultural communities and the Sikh community specifically. The role of multicultural-ism and citizenship should be the building of bridges and not barriers.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to take this opportunity to draw your attention to a measure taken by our government to support Montreal's economic development over the next few years. I do so on behalf of the members of the Montreal caucus I have the honour to chair.
Monday, the Minister of National Health and Welfare, who is responsible for the Federal Office of Regional Development, announced that $150 million would be allocated by the government to support projects in sectors that would afford the best prospects for Montreal.
This initiative by our government is well suited to the partnership that exists today between government and

June 17, 1992
the private sector and which is aimed at making Montreal a world class industrial and technological centre.
In concluding, Mr. Speaker, I would like to add that I have the firm conviction that with this injection of $150 million Montreal will be able to further enhance its role as a centre of excellence for a variety of disciplines.
I would like to recall the work done by members of the Montreal caucus who made this initiative a success and, again, our thanks to the minister.

Mr. Speaker, three days ago the national police of El Salvador kidnapped Jose Adolfo Rodas Rivera without a judicial order and are holding him in police headquarters, likely torturing him.
Rodas is a leader in the Christian Committee for the Displaced People, the group that has promoted the peaceful return of peasant families to war-tom areas of El Salvador.
The police are the force of the old military elite trying to block the peaceful return of democracy to El Salvador. With continuing United States' money and arms, El Salvador continues to drive some people to become refugees
Therefore, this is no time for Canada to begin dismantling our laws for giving shelter to refugees. We must not classify El Salvador as a safe country from which no real refugees come. We must not return Salvadorans to the United States without first examining their refugee claims, as Bill C-86 would allow us to do.
Instead, Canada should call on El Salvador to release Rodas unharmed, and on the United States to cease arming the Salvadoran security forces.
 *

Mr. Speaker, I would like to bring to the attention of this House and my
colleagues an important event that will be held in the town of Lacombe in my riding on July 1, 1992.
In honour of Canada's 125th birthday and in memory of Roland B. Michener, late Governor General of Canada, who was bom in Lacombe, Alberta, the town has requested the donation of trees from communities across Canada as a living tribute. They hope to plant 125 trees in Michener Park, each one of which will have the name of the donating municipality engraved on a plaque. It is hoped by this to symbolically bring Canada together.
I would like to congratulate the town of Lacombe and all the constituents involved for their enthusiasm, dedication, and for this special way of celebrating Canada's 125th anniversary.

In my riding, the St. Germain School has started a unique project on Canadian unity. Youngsters in the fifth grade studied present day Canada and asked a number of questions which I will quote here.
(1) Will Canada separate? (2) What will happen in that case? (3) What can we, as students, do to prevent this from happening?
What did they recommend? I will read it to you:
We want to do something for Canadian unity, and we have a message: A puzzle is worthless if there is a piece missing! We made a big flag which was signed by more than 600 people at school. There is a message on the flag: Long live a united Canada! Let's talk. Let's communicate.

The message is clear. It is not unlike the others I received from College Louis-Riel when they held a citizenship court, or from H. S. Paul and Samuel Burland schools, including the many hundreds of other students when they held their Canada 125 celebrations: "Let's keep our country together by talking to each other".
Merci, thank you to all of our young people.
June 17, 1992

Mr. Speaker, this afternoon I would like to draw the attention of honourable members to the sudden passing of a senior federal official.
Yesterday, we were told about the death of Mr. Jean-Claude Lebel, who for the past three years had been deputy minister responsible for the Federal Office of Regional Development-Quebec, of which he was both the principal artisan and leading light.
He will be remembered by his employees, his federal and Quebec counterparts and his many co-workers and friends, not only as a dedicated and tireless public servant but also as an ardent defender of regional development in Quebec.
Speaking on behalf of all members of the Quebec Conservative caucus and on behalf of the members of this House, I wish to offer our sincere condolences to Mr. Lebel's family.

Mr. Speaker, I rise today to advise Canadians that this government is ignoring the democratic process by rushing Bill C-80 through committee stage, denying experts in the field who unanimously oppose this legislation an opportunity to appear before the committee.
This bill hammers the last nail in the coffin of universality and will profoundly affect the lives of poor children. Yet the groups and individuals who work on the front lines dealing with these children are being denied the chance to say how the bill affects them.
The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare has said that she does not see the need for social policy groups to present briefs to the committee because the bill is essentially a tax bill. Even the Minister of National Health and Welfare, the minister responsible for children, is not slated to appear.
When will the government stop looking to expensive tax lawyers for answers and start listening to what hungry children and advocates are saying?
I urge members of the government side to keep the debate open, even though they might not want to hear what the experts are going to say, and allow witnesses the time they need to present briefs to the committee. When is the government going to listen to the ruinous effects its policies are having on Canada's children?

Mr. Speaker, I would like to thank Bernard Valcourt, the Minister of Employment and Immigration, for bringing some common sense to our immigration system. In my riding, in town hall meetings, in my mail and in personal interventions, constituents of Halton-Peel have been asking for a system that is fair, that costs less to run for taxpayers, and yet maintains the humanitarian reputation of Canada.
Among the much-needed reforms we now see is a guarantee that refugees coming to this country will be legitimate. Speedy family reunification for immigrants allowed into Canada, encouraging immigrants to come here who have the skill and capital that Canada needs, and positioning those immigrants in the geographic areas where they are needed in this country and finally, tough new rules to keep criminals and terrorists out of Canada.
These are simple requests from the people of my riding and I would like to thank the minister for listening. As we all know, the government that listens is the government that lasts.

Mr. Speaker, on April 6, 1992 I placed a question on the Order Paper related to projects funded by the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency and requested a response within 45 days.
Today is the 72nd day since I made my request and I have not yet received a response.

S. ft 31
People throughout my riding and the rest of Atlantic Canada have the right to know what projects ACOA has funded. People want to know what the agency is doing with their tax dollars.
With unemployment in Prince Edward Island over 18 per cent, it is hard to see how ACOA is helping Prince Edward Island.
I call upon the minister responsible for ACOA to shed some light on the situation and answer my question.

Mr. Speaker, today I would like to make the House and all Canadians aware of the courageous effort of 13-year-old Virginie Lariviere following her young sister's violent death. Virginie has undertaken to have a million Canadians sign a petition to reduce violence on television.
As more and more studies show a connection between violence on television and violence in our society, it is our duty to act and ensure that our regulations reflect the kind of society we want.
In the wake of her sister Marie-Eve's horrible death, Virginie Lariviere gives us a lesson in courage, humani-tarianism and dedication that should inspire us all.
I therefore ask for the support and involvement of all hon. members to help distribute Virginie Lariviere's petition throughout the country and to work to reduce violence on television and violence in all its forms.

Mr. Speaker, yesterday the Standing Committee on Human Rights and the Status of Disabled Persons unanimously declared that the federal government should reinstate the Court Challenges Program, which was abolished in the most recent federal budget.
The Court Challenges Program, which is to end in September 1992, enables disadvantaged groups to have their cases heard in court. The committee notes that
without this program access to the recourses provided in the Charter will no doubt be limited to groups and individuals that are already favoured financially and politically.
The government must recognize its responsibility to this country's minorities, like the French-speaking minorities, and restore the Court Challenges Program which has proven to be a fundamental tool for recognizing the rights of francophone and Acadian communities.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the residents of my riding of Sarnia-Lambton will applaud the government's proposed changes to the Immigration Act. My constituents will recognize that the changes respond to the realities of the 1990s and provide the government with tools to maintain the integrity of the system.
My constituents will welcome the news of proposed measures which will streamline the refugee system and provide better service, curtail the abuse of immigration and refugee systems, including better controls at the border, as well as impose time limits and standard processing time to help eliminate the backlogs.
At the same time, I know they will also applaud the government's renewed commitment to reunite families, protect refugees and promote economic development.
Finally, I know my constituents will appreciate a reformed and revitalized immigration program which is fair, balanced and effective, a program designed to best serve their interests.

Mr. Speaker, seven years ago, Madame Henriette Haddad disappeared in the streets of Beirut.
Today, for the first time, there is encouraging news suggesting that Henriette Haddad may indeed be alive. Her family and friends have worked tirelessly for her release over the years and have often expressed their frustration at the lack of support of their government.
June 17, 1992

Today Angeline Fournier, co-chairman of the committee to free Henriette Haddad, said that a high official of the Iranian embassy in Paris had told them the fundamentalist Iranian group was prepared to release her on humanitarian grounds. This group is the Iranian Revolutionary Guards.
As Madame Fournier said, this is the opening of the door for the first time. They are calling upon the Prime Minister and the Secretary of State for External Affairs to provide help in this very delicate matter.
I would urge the government to provide full assistance to the family and friends so that very soon Henriette Haddad will indeed return home to Canada.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the Prime Minister.
Provincial health ministers are meeting in Ottawa with their federal counterpart to discuss the increasing costs of our health care system and looking for ways to deal with this problem. We are very worried at this point, because Canadians know the health care system we have in this country is the best in the world. They are afraid that provincial governments want to introduce user fees which will have a very negative impact, especially on the poorest members of our society.
I therefore want to ask the Prime Minister whether he can give Canadians assurances that our national health care system will remain universal and free for all Canadians and especially for the neediest members of our society.

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have said many times that the federal government's position on health care has been the same ever since the Canada Health Act was passed.
Oral Questions
Last September in Winnipeg, at a meeting of all Canadian health ministers, the first principle to be reconfirmed by all provinces was the guarantee that the five main criteria-universality, accessibility, portability, and so forth-would be maintained. The federal government's position has not changed.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have a supplementary for the minister.
I am glad to hear the minister say the government's position has not changed, but will the government make the necessary arrangements to ensure the provinces will not have to change the system?
As a result of the 1990 and 1991 budgets, the Minister of Finance has created a situation where, in a matter of just a few years, the provinces will no longer receive direct payments from the government for health care. Could the minister inform the House that the government will review this situation in order to keep in place the necessary mechanisms to maintain the integrity of our health system by continuing transfer payments to the provinces, as well as transfers of tax points?

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I may remind the Leader of the Opposition that cash payments in the form of tax points were requested by the provinces when he was a member of the government, if I am not mistaken.
However, in September the provinces also admitted that considering the $60 billion invested in the health care system in this country, which makes it the costliest public health care system in the world, it was agreed that in fact it was not a problem of resources but rather of better managing the funds available.
Last night, the Minister of Finance and I met HEAL, a health care lobby group. They too agreed that the problem with the health care system in Canada is not, basically, a resource problem. The money is there-$60 billion-so it is more a matter of management. The provinces, from New Brunswick to Ontario and from Newfoundland to British Columbia, have on the whole taken on a number of responsibilities, which leads us to believe that we are on the right track. Together with the

June 17, 1992
Oral Questions
provinces, we are trying to maintain-as the Leader of the Opposition said, and I agree with him-the main criteria for the system, with the knowledge that the capacity to finance the system is there, Mr. Speaker.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I would like to ask a supplementary question of the minister. In the discussions he is having with the provinces at this moment, will the minister tell them very clearly that there is absolutely no possibility in Canada that we will go for user fees in medicare for Canadians and that hospitals in Canada are for sick people, not for rich people and that this very important regime will remain as it is for the benefit of all Canadians?

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, all the provinces in light of the resources we provide are subjected to the Canada Health Act which directly forbids any province charging what we call a user fee. There is no problem at that level. We would have to amend the legislation to be able to do that.
To the credit of the provinces also, we have to say they are trying to do a lot, trying to manage the resources they have in spite of increasing costs. It increased during the eighties about 12 per cent, which is too much for the capacity we have to pay today.
We give the guarantee that the law will not be amended, that we will keep it. At the same time, Canadians have to know, and I think they share this view, that all efforts have to be made to protect the best system in the world, but within their capacity they have to pay for it.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the minister of health.
This week's report on breast cancer highlights a social problem of near epidemic proportions. Last year, this government gave the Medical Research Council $849,000 and only $189,000 of that money went to direct research for breast cancer.
Will the minister and this government recognize that funding for this research is a matter of urgency and provide the recommended funding now that is recommended in this report?
Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health
and Welfare): Mr. Speaker, I gave an answer to the same kind of question to my friend from British Columbia yesterday.
I said we definitely have to look at all the questions of research on cancer and breast cancer in a particular way. I repeat what I said yesterday. I believe that all those issues dealing with women and health have been seen too many times from a man's perspective.
Having said that, the hon. member has to know, and it is easy to know, that funding for breast cancer is not predetermined. We can fund $3 million, $4 million or $5 million now if the project submitted to NHRDP and the Medical Research Council has the quality to warrant funding. Yes, I am ready to give more money and to at least consider the possibility if it can be confirmed that any project dealing with breast cancer has been turned down because of a problem with money.
It never happened to my knowledge or to the knowledge of the Medical Research Council.

Mr. Speaker, yes, I heard the minister's comments yesterday. If you ask any pure scientist, $189,000 is not enough money.
There are five women whom I know in the Pratt family, two with breast cancer and three of them very high risk. We know that cancer runs in families. We know that there is a shortage of radiation technologists. We know there is a shortage of radiation equipment. We know there is not enough research money and this is a women's issue.
Will the minister indicate to this House what this government's action plan is going to be to deal with this very serious situation?

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, once again, I think that I confirmed twice yesterday and again today that I am ready to listen and look at what we can do. Immediately I see a kind of slippage of the member when she says we have to provide more equipment. She knows that at that level the provinces have full responsibility and the federal level cannot go to the province of Ontario and say it will supply equipment.
Once again, I repeat what I said, we have to be more sensitive to breast cancer particularly. I am ready to look at the full report provided yesterday and to do my best. We have not predetermined money. Maybe $800,000 is not enough, but it has not been determined by the department or by the Medical Research Council. It is based on projects submitted by researchers. Maybe we
June 17, 1992

should support more research, particularly among women, and maybe it would help to supply more money.

Mr. Speaker, I also have a question for the minister of health.
The joint meeting of the federal-provincial ministers of health and finance is extremely important for the survival of our national medicare program. It is no secret that the minister's colleagues are primarily concerned about the unilateral federal withdrawal from the cost-shared partnership in financing health care.
Does the minister agree with the statement by the Newfoundland minister of health, Chris Decker, that the federal government cannot afford a universal health care system or, in the words of Mr. Decker: "They talk about it but they cannot deliver".
What has happened to the federal government's commitment and obligations under medicare to all Canadians?

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the member is wrong when he says that the provinces are particularly upset by the unilateral withdrawal of resources.
If he looks at information that we released in September in Winnipeg, all the provinces, except Quebec because it was not there, but including British Columbia agreed at the time that the problem is not a question of money. Once again, it is the most expensive public system in the world. We have to use the resources we have. In that respect we work with the provinces and continue to do that in light of the fact that we can improve the management and the system and keep the best system in the world.

Mr. Speaker, my supplementary is to the same minister.
The minister of health for B.C. said: "I think medicare is being threatened and largely responsible are the federal cuts in transfer payments to the provinces". The National Council on Welfare, the government's own advisory group, has calculated that the cuts to the federal financing formula for health will amount to more than $60 billion by the year 2000.
Oral Questions
Can the minister tell the House what kind of a health care system will result from these unilateral cuts? Will it be a patchwork with different standards in each province, including user fees, higher premiums, extra billing by doctors or a two-tiered U.S. style health care system?

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I do not know how many times I have to tell the member that there were no cuts. There were reductions in the way we transfer payments. Of course, that is the usual language of the NDP and we are used to that. I would appreciate having the same kind of interesting question I got from the member for Nepean.
I repeat, $60 billion in the health care system in Canada is a lot of money. It is the most expensive in the world. We are trying to work within those resources. I can say that the provinces are encouraged to do that. I will continue to work with the provinces which want to work in that respect.

Mr. Speaker, my supplementary question is to the same minister.
Can the minister explain how medicare can still be considered a cost-shared program when the federal share has declined from 50 per cent in 1980 under successive Liberal and Tory governments to 31 per cent that it is today? How much lower will the federal share shrink in the remaining three years of the present freeze? Will it be 25 per cent, 20 per cent, 15 per cent or even lower?

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the member should know that maybe the direct transfer payments have been reduced, but the tax points have increased since 1982-83, which means that we give more money today than we gave 10 years ago.
The meeting tonight between the ministers of finance and the ministers of health will not be to say we will put in a billion dollars more. We will be there to determine how we can keep the system working the way it does, keeping in mind that we have to protect the system in light of the fact that we have reduced resources at the federal level. The ministers agree with that. They agreed last September and they will continue to agree.

June 17, 1992
Oral Questions
If we put in more money as the member wants, we would just have the same problem we face today because we inherited a $500 billion debt. Fortunately the NDP is not there or it would be $1,000 billion.

Mr. Speaker, this question is for the Prime Minister.
Yesterday the Minister of Employment and Immigration tabled his voluminous immigration amendments which included extensive management and enforcement measures but paid little attention to humanitarian concerns.
Since the minister had the opportunity, why did he not provide an appeal on the merits for refugees whose applications have been rejected, as recommended by many NGOs, churches and the legal community?
The Refugee Board is not perfect, and without an appeal process the system is seriously flawed. Now is the time for an appeal process.

speakeroldname: Hon. Monique Vezina (Minister of State (Employment and Immigration) and Minister of State (Seniors)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Seniors); Minister of State (Employment and Immigration)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member opposite should read the bill carefully and he would see that in subsections 114(2), (6) and (5) we seek the authority to apply selection criteria.
The bill tabled by my colleague responsible for employment and immigration maintains Canada's humanitarian tradition as it pertains to economic requirements and employment that we must use in the immigration model. I wish to assure this House again that we will continue to respect refugee claims.
The bill tabled yesterday simply adapts the act to the realities of 1992 so that we can have a fair, equitable and efficient system.

Mr. Speaker, the minister did not even answer my question. I
was asking about an appeal on the merits process. She did not address that question.

As an alternative, why did the Minister of Employment and Immigration not specify and provide objective criteria for admitting refugees on humanitarian grounds? The minister almost eliminated this useful provision that allowed the most deserving cases to appeal. Will the minister or the government consider amendments to the bill to make better use of this provision and provide a fairer appeal process?

speakeroldname: Hon. Monique Vezina (Minister of State (Employment and Immigration) and Minister of State (Seniors)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Seniors); Minister of State (Employment and Immigration)
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, the amendments made to the bill yesterday-or rather the suggested amendments, I should say, because we will have an opportunity through the parliamentary process to express our point of view-make procedures into regulations. So regulations rather than procedures will make it possible for applicants to appeal using the regular process. In any case, everyone in Canada will be able to exercise their right to appeal and each case will be heard on its merits.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Agriculture.
Last night we saw the spectacle on national television of B.C. vegetable producers ploughing down their crops because United States farmers are dumping low priced, low value vegetables into the Canadian market.
We know that the government in the free trade negotiation gave up the right to have a seasonal tariff. I want to ask the minister what the government is going to do. What action is going to be taken to keep these producers in business?

Mr. Speaker, I know my hon. friend did not deliberately misinform the House.
June 17, 1992

We have a snap-back provision that was negotiated in the trade agreement between Canada and the United States which has been used by the government when necessary.
The hon. member should be aware that the association which represents these producers requested a hearing be held into the dumping allegations. They have been working with the Department of National Revenue to assemble that information. The Department of National Revenue is co-operating in presenting this case. We have worked hand in hand with our sister departments and we will work with the producers.

Mr. Speaker, the minister knows, as every producer across this country knows, that the snap-back provision is absolutely useless. It just does not protect the industry.
The Department of National Revenue published a press release last week saying it would be making a determination in 90 days. That is simply unacceptable. The crops will all be ploughed down within 90 days.
Will the government bring in a determination for an anti-dumping duty by June 23 when the House rises? Will the minister give that kind of commitment to those producers today?

Mr. Speaker, as beneficial as that might appear, the hon. member would be the first to complain to our trading partners if they attempted to run roughshod over a process that was established to allow it to take place.
Those critics of doom and gloom who identified that the free trade agreement would cause the destruction of agriculture have to recognize fact. The fact is that the number of farms has reduced at a lower rate in the last five years in Canada than any time since 1941.
Another thing the hon. member and other colleagues should know is that agricultural food exports to the United States since the free trade agreement have increased 29 per cent, almost 10 per cent a year. The hon. member should recognize that.

Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the Prime Minister.
Oral Questions
Both the Nova Scotia government order establishing the inquiry into the Westray mine disaster and the provincial statute authorizing the order specifically restricts the inquiry to matters, and I quote, "in relation to which the legislature may make laws".
In other words, every aspect of the disaster within federal jurisdiction, such things as federal government investigations and safety assessments or regional development funding or cabinet assessment, is beyond the scope of the Nova Scotia inquiry.
Will the Prime Minister now admit that all the government's assurances for the last month that no federal inquiry was needed were in fact completely incorrect, that the Nova Scotia inquiry cannot inquire into strictly federal actions and responsibilities in the disaster?
He should go to Hollywood. The walk would do him good.

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext: No, Mr. Speaker.

That is not entirely comforting, Mr. Speaker, so I would ask a question of the Acting Prime Minister.
The inquiry commissioner, Justice Richard, himself said yesterday when talking about the huge volume of documents his inquiry already had to review:
I have no jurisdiction as a provincial inquiry over documents
outside the province.
The justice himself recognizes the restrictions on his inquiry.
Will the government now stop trying to hide its own actions and responsibilities behind a provincial inquiry which cannot investigate them and call a federal inquiry which can?

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, it is certainly true the judge did say that he did not have jurisdiction over documents issuing from a federal jurisdiction, but we sent them to him anyway.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Prime Minister. It concerns a matter of paramount importance to the people of Newfoundland and Labrador: the state of the fishery.

June 17, 1992
Oral Questions
Yesterday in St. Anthony, Newfoundland nearly 1,000 men and women marched and demonstrated, calling upon governments and calling upon politicians of every stripe to acknowledge and to deal constructively with the crisis in the fishery. These people have been without income since May 15 and have no prospect of future income in the face of the imminent moratorium on northern cod stocks.
I want to ask the Prime Minister whether or not the government is prepared to consider now making available assistance to sustain these families until such time as a long-term program to rebuild cod stocks is put in place by the minister of fisheries and long-term assistance made available to those who are going to be displaced because of conservation measures.

Mr. Speaker, the government is very concerned about the situation of the fishermen not only in St. Anthony but throughout Newfoundland and Labrador and Atlantic Canada where their incomes have dropped quite dramatically because of the problem of cod stocks and fishing stocks generally for reasons that we are acquainted with.
One of the reasons why the government in 1990 responded with a $584 million Atlantic Fisheries Adjustment Program, and I think almost a $40 million catch failure program the next year, was precisely to accommodate this sad reality. The situation has not improved and the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans has been working on a program that we think will be helpful and constructive.
I have been talking to some of the union leaders in Newfoundland as late as last evening. The minister of fisheries, who is travelling in Atlantic Canada, will be talking to me again tonight. We hope to move forward and respond to this very real problem that is hurting all the fishing families in Newfoundland and Labrador.

Mr. Speaker, members on this side of the House from Newfoundland, indeed members from Atlantic Canada, appreciate that the government has put assistance programs in place in 1990 and 1991. Federal governments going back over 10 years have had to assist the Atlantic fishing industry on occasion.
I want to make clear to the Prime Minister what the families are asking for now. What they are saying is that they understand that whatever action must be taken to rebuild those stocks must be undertaken no matter what the cost, including the cost to families. Until such time as the long-term plan is put in place, as it must be, and until such time as long-term compensation measures are worked out, as we are confident they will be, in the interim, just to sustain the basics of life, to put bread and butter on the table, can Atlantic fishing families, in particular in Newfoundland and Labrador, expect this government to intervene to provide them with some economic assistance soon, now if possible?

Mr. Speaker, I think my friend quite properly divides the problem in two. The long-term problem will partly be resolved as a result of the UNCED conference in Rio and other long-term initiatives to revive the cod stocks off Newfoundland and Labrador. That is certainly a long-term problem. I think we are in general agreement that the minister of fisheries, for example, did a tremendous job in Rio in regard to the protection of the interests of Newfoundland and Labrador.
With regard to the more immediate problem, as we know Rick Cashin is chairing a task force in regard to the specific problem. The minister of fisheries and the member for St. John's East have been making specific recommendations to the government as to how the Government of Canada can assist the fishermen and the communities in the short term, which I think is the problem raised by my hon. friend.
The record indicates that when the people of Newfoundland and Labrador needed assistance this government, the Government of Canada, did not fail to respond. I am waiting to hear from the minister of fisheries in regard to his ideas. When he has a specific program I am satisfied that the government will respond in a fair and I think helpful way to the fishermen of Newfoundland and Labrador.

Mr. Speaker, yesterday a Newfoundland inshore fisherman from Fogo Island, Mr. Larry Donahue, trying hard to catch fish, watched helplessly as 50 of his nets were dragged up and destroyed by a factory trawler from France in the northern cod zone.
June 17, 1992

How can the Government of Canada not only give France cod quotas in the northern cod zone but now notify the Canadian Embassy in Paris that it is going to give France more quotas in the northern cod zone from July 1 until September 30 when the boundary dispute has been settled?

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the boundary dispute has been settled. I think it has been settled very much to Canada's satisfaction and in the interest of the Newfoundland fishery. I should point out in terms of what is happening right now, the quotas that have been granted now until the end of September follow directly from the agreement of March 1989. There is a legal obligation to continue with that.
No one will be happier than the minister of fisheries and the Government of Canada once this obligation is completed. We will be in a position to fully manage as a result of the decision that was made by the boundaries commission.

Mr. Speaker, the 1989 agreement signed by the Government of Canada gave France northern cod quotas for two years "in proportion to the Canadian offshore allocation".
Does the government not realize that there has been a moratorium on the Canadian offshore allocation for the past six months and any proportion of zero is still zero even for France?
Why is the government giving northern cod quotas to France illegally?

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, unfortunately the way article 5 reads is not the way the hon. member has described it.
The 15 per cent that was granted was based on the law. The decision did not come down before May 15. The hon. member is trying to over-simplify what has been a difficult and technical problem for us. After September 30 we are going to be in an excellent position, thanks to the fact that we won a very important international case which has the best possible implications for the fishery in Newfoundland.
Oral Questions YOUNG OFFENDERS

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the distinguished Minister of Justice.
Increasingly, Canadians are becoming quite disturbed by the punishment meted out to young offenders under 17 years of age, especially if they have been convicted of a homicide or brutal assault.
What action does the minister intend to take to stop the giving of a slight slap on the wrist and young offenders being told to be good and go back home?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I thank the hon. member who is a man of rare discernment and good taste for the question.
The question is a serious one. It has been dealt with to some degree already by members of this House in passing amendments to the Young Offenders Act and of later statutes which provide a greater range of options available to judges in transferring young offenders' charges on very serious crimes to adult court thereby providing a larger range of sentence and parole options.
As the hon. member will know, there is considerable concern in this country with the Young Offenders Act. Some of it is more a reflection of how the act is implemented than what is in it itself. We are undertaking with the active participation of members of this House, in particular members of our caucus, a review of the Young Offenders Act in order to try and address the concerns the hon. member raises.
Confidence of the Canadian people in the justice system is absolutely vital. We wish to address the concerns of Canadians with respect to the Young Offenders Act and we are geared to doing that.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister.
Many Canadians are deeply concerned about the continued imprisonment in Brazilian jails on 28-year sentences of two young Canadians, Christine Lamont and David Spencer.

June 17, 1992
Oral Questions
I want to ask the Prime Minister to confirm that he raised the plight of Lamont and Spencer with Brazilian President Collor during his recent trip to Rio for the earth summit.
Will the Prime Minister indicate to the House and to the families of Christine Lamont and David Spencer the nature of the representations the Prime Minister made and the response of the Brazilian president?

Mr. Speaker, I am happy to confirm to my hon. friend that I did indeed raise this very serious case with the President of Brazil in a meeting with him a few days ago in Rio.
I put forward views that I thought would be helpful and appropriate in regard to that situation. He is taking them into consideration and I would expect that we will be advised of the decision of his government.

Mr. Speaker, I would certainly be interested to know what the views were of the Prime Minister with respect to an appropriate resolution of this.
I would like to ask my supplementary of the Secretary of State for External Affairs. She knows that last week the House of Commons justice committee unanimously agreed to urge the minister to request the expulsion of Lamont and Spencer in accordance with Brazilian law and in accordance with Canada's obligations under international human rights conventions.
My question is straightforward: Will the minister now accept this unanimous all-party recommendation, show leadership on behalf of these young Canadians and seek their expulsion from Brazil and their return to their families in Canada?

Mr. Speaker, the minister has been very troubled by and interested in this case. She called me in Brazil to advise me of the unanimous report that had just been released, I think it was that night, by the committee.
I examined with Brazilian officials the concept that they were sitting around waiting for a request for an expulsion to which they would respond immediately. This is not the case. This is not an accurate assumption and people ought to set it aside.
I did raise with the President the opportunities under Brazil's constitution available to him and to the Government of Canada in considering the plight of these two prisoners, for whom we all feel a great deal of concern and anxiety. After a good discussion with the President, I left with him an invitation to communicate with me as quickly as he could regarding a resolution on it.

Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans.
I had the opportunity at the request of the then minister to chair the last national recreational fisheries conference in 1989. Another such conference is being held in September of this year.
I am concerned to hear there are signals emanating from the Department of Fisheries and Oceans which indicate a diminishing priority for recreational fisheries in that department. The most important signal is the apparent termination of the national recreational fisheries survey.
That survey is one of the most important tools we have for managing the recreational fishery in Canada. Among other things, it indicates that sports fishing is a major contributor to our economy to the extent of about $5 billion directly and it involves six million citizens.
I would like to ask the parliamentary secretary whether the recreational fishery survey has actually been cancelled and if so, why? Does this reflect or reveal a diminishing priority for recreational fisheries in the department?

Mr. Speaker, my question is to the Solicitor General.
Media reports today allege that the names of CSIS informers are "now routinely given to politicians". If this is accurate, it is scandalous.
Will the minister tell this House whether this report has any foundation? If so, will he immediately investigate this serious breach of national security and report to Parliament on the precise steps he is taking to rectify it?

speakeroldname: Hon. Doug Lewis (Solicitor General of Canada):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I am pleased that this matter has been raised in the House. I want to assure my friend that names of CSIS sources are not and in fact in the course of my tenure as Solicitor General have not been revealed to the Solicitor General.

These reports indicate very clearly that even the government's own officials are questioning the minister's authority to be in possession of this information.
Will he give this House his assurance that this sensitive informant information in his hands will not be shared with fellow politicians and that information gathered by CSIS will be monitored closely within the rules of law?
Will he commit now to report to Parliament either to the national security subcommittee or to the Security Intelligence Review Committee on this serious matter?

speakeroldname: Hon. Doug Lewis (Solicitor General of Canada):
speechtext:

CSIS sources are not revealed to me in the course of the conduct of my operations as Solicitor General. From time to time, I am made aware of the circumstances surrounding a particular sensitive operation, but never the name.

Canada Post Corporation announced its plan to rationalize the nation's mail sorting system. That announcement identified 92 communities where some 295 jobs are in jeopardy as well as service to those communities.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs.

June 17, 1992
Oral Questions
There is an awareness out there in Canada by consumers and small businesses that what the banks lose on their real estate investments they will pick from the pockets of consumers and small businesses.
Some banks have announced a freeze. That is like closing the door after the horses have eaten all the hay, all the oats and then left.
My question to this minister who is also the Minister of State for Agriculture: Will the minister call in the banks and tell them to roll back their service charges and then freeze them?

speakeroldname: Hon. Pierre Blais (Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs and Minister of State (Agriculture)):
speakerposition: Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Minister of State (Agriculture)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, a week ago or maybe a little more, the Minister of Finance and I said in this House that we had told the banks that there was no question of making consumers pay for any losses incurred by any of them in real estate transactions. We reassured the House on this point several times.
My colleague also knows that I personally met the bankers' representatives to ask them to lower credit card interest rates-this is the subject that concerns him. Rates have fallen nearly 5 per cent and are now about 7 per cent, the lowest in the past 20 years. This is quite something and is due to this government's economic policies. I believe that it is all to the good for consumers.

Mr. Speaker, I have only one thing to say to the Minister of State for Agriculture and the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs, that is horse feathers.
My question had nothing to do with credit card interest rates. We are talking about bank service charges. I will repeat again to the minister, will he call in the banks and order a roll back on the service charges and then a freeze, not for three banks, but for the six biggest banks?

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Finance who has indicated that he is looking for ways to help Canada compete by improving our municipal infrastructure as long as it is within the existing fiscal framework.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I wish to give notice of my intention to move the adjournment of the House pursuant to Standing Order 52, to discuss a specific matter requiring urgent consideration, namely the plight of fishermen and
fish plant workers in Newfoundland and Labrador who have been without any source of income since May 15.
These individuals require urgent interim economic assistance to sustain the basics of life until such time as the Government of Canada, under the guidance of the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans, makes final decisions on a fisheries management program and provides compensation for those who will be displaced as a result of conservation measures.
I have a brief comment. Members of the fishing community in Newfoundland and Labrador and, indeed, throughout Atlantic Canada, are aware that Parliament is scheduled to adjourn within a matter of a few parliamentary sitting days. They are aware that dramatic and drastic action must be taken to sustain the cod species, the cod stocks. They are prepared for the consequences of those decisions but they want, I believe legitimately, their voice to be heard before the House rises for a scheduled summer recess, and that both the problems and the potential that exist in the current environment be discussed in this place.
They sense that the deep calamity they are experiencing is one that has been discussed and has been understood and has been acknowledged and has been dealt with by the Parliament of Canada. It is in that spirit and in the spirit of the exchange in Question Period today that I make this request on an urgent basis, Mr. Speaker.

They would rather have the government keep that 37 cents each month than be humiliated in that fashion. My constituents are concerned that there are still thousands and thousands of Canadian seniors who live in poverty, that in fact the 37 cent increase in their pensions in April 1992 not only ignores the needs of many of them but is an insult to them, and that moreover the federal government has a primary responsibility to ensure the adequacy of seniors' pensions.

Scotians on something that exists right at the grassroots of one's riding, and that is the concern that my petitioners have about the variance between federal truck rates and provincial truck rates and the problems that this causes in predatory pricing.
My petitioners call upon Parliament to enact legislation for the adoption of minimum rate schedules for dump trucks on federal projects at rates not less than the minimum truck haul rates and conditions set by each province where the federal project is to be undertaken. I so humbly pray on their behalf.

Mr. Speaker, pursuant to Standing Order 36,1 have the honour to present to the House a petition from a number of my constituents living in the Emestown and Napanee areas situated in my riding of Hastings-Frontenac-Lennox and Addington.
These petitioners are supporting the government's commitment as stated in the Speech from the Throne on May 13,1991 to introduce legislation which would permit a national referendum on the Constitution if necessary.

Mr. Speaker, I have the honour to present a petition which is signed by residents of Ottawa, Gatineau and Hull collected by Janice Manchee from the Public Service Alliance of Canada, Human Rights Division.
The petitioners note that in October 1985 the subcommittee on equality rights of the justice committee unanimously recommended to Parliament that the Canadian Human Rights Act be amended to prohibit discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation in all areas of federal jurisdiction.
They note that the government promised in March 1986 to implement this recommendation but that some six years later the government has yet to act. They point out that the Canadian Human Rights Commission has called for this amendment and that a number of provincial governments have acted.
Therefore, they call upon Parliament to ensure that government and Parliament act to bring forward immediately an amendment to add sexual orientation to the Canadian Human Rights Act as a prohibited ground of discrimination.

I have another petition which is signed by residents of Vancouver and Burnaby which notes that Steven Ogunwuyi, a Nigerian of 23 years of age, was unwittingly implicated in an unsuccessful coup attempt against the unelected president of Nigeria. It notes that prison conditions in Nigeria are appalling and that other people implicated in the coup have been executed after totally unacceptable trials.
The petition notes that he has escaped from Nigeria and is seeking refugee status in Canada and he fears for his life. Therefore, the petitioners urge the House of Commons to request the Minister of Employment and Immigration to allow Steven Ogunwuyi to remain in Canada on compassionate grounds.

Mr. Speaker, I have a petition signed by 210 students and staff from Sir Frederick Banting Junior Secondary School in Coquitlam.
The petitioners say that Dupont is the world's largest producer of CFCs with a major plant here in Canada capable of producing up to 18,000 tonnes annually. For almost 20 years the company has continued to produce these chemicals, despite scientific evidence linking them to the destruction of the ozone layer. They say that ozone in southern Canada will be depleted by 15 per cent this year, resulting in a staggering 26 per cent increase in skin cancer, and that the only real answer is to stop producing those ozone-destroying chemicals now.
The petitioners demand that Dupont stop its production of ozone-destroying chemicals now.
