flawed because it does not provide for consistent treatment of federally regulated employees in the Public Service. The government in fact had models to choose from, models that work quite well. There is the Canada Pension Plan with automatic division of credits or the flexible provisions of the Pension Benefits Standards Act. The government chose neither of those two models.
Instead, the government decided to limit the benefit distribution to one method only, the much more restrictive, cumbersome and less fair lump sum transfer. This method is not easily acceptable and it has a lot of built-in time delays and court costs. The evaluation of these lump sum amounts fails to take into account many factors.
There were a number of options presented at committee stage that would have improved the bill. Unfortunately the government did not accept them.
The key thing to remember in this legislation is that it does in fact make some small measure of improvement because it does allow for pension splitting, even though it is an imperfect model.
My concern which I tried to articulate in the comments I made is that it will not benefit those women who have been cheated out of a fair share of the pensions they, in fact, worked for over the many years they may have been married.
I gave the example of the woman who was the spouse of a diplomat. She was married for some 30 years and was not allowed to work by conditions of her husband's employment. By this government's own conditions, she was not allowed to have employment. When that marriage split up she had no provision to access part of the pension she had helped her husband earn.
Now this bill does nothing to remedy that situation for those women who have been cheated out of a lifetime of earnings and a share in the pension plan.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker, for this opportunity to speak to Bill C-55, which concerns changes in the superannuation plan for the Public Service, the RCMP and the Armed Forces. I estimate that in my own riding of Carleton- Gloucester the majority of my constituents are employed either by the Public Service, the RCMP or the Armed Forces.

Government Orders
These employees have all contributed to the plan, as they would in the private sector. Some people, especially on the government benches, claim that public servants are getting a free ride. I can assure you that public servants, like their colleagues in the private sector, have contributed their fair share to their pension plan.
Public servants are professionals who dedicate their lives, and do so very conscientiously, to serving Canada's communities. They are paid to do this, but they have to consider the future. Public servants must have a pension plan that is fair. It is up to us as parliamentarians to ensure that public servants have a pension plan that is both fair and equitable, so that it can meet the needs of public servants when they are retired.
The superannuation fund now contains almost $75 billion, or it will in a matter of months or, to be more specific, towards the end of the year.
Surprisingly, the government is the self-appointed administrator, comptroller, trustee and manager of the fund. The government has a monopoly. It is the official trustee of this pension plan, so it should be honest and fair in dealing with its employees. It is not a matter of handouts but of being fair.
We all know the government uses this money for its own purposes, either to pay off the deficit or the national debt. Contrary to the provisions of the Pension Benefits Standards Act, 1985, employees and retired employees are not included on the Board. The Pension Benefits Standards Act, 1985 is an act respecting pension plans organized and administered for the benefit of persons employed in connection with certain federal works, undertakings and businesses. This act was assented to on June 27, 1986. The administration of pension plans will, according to the act, include at least one member of the pension committee chosen by plan members.
Let me ask you this, Mr. Speaker: Do employees have a representative on the pension fund advisory committee? Do retired civil servants have one? The answer is no, unlike other programs in various provinces.
This bill also provides for retired contributors to be represented on the management committee by a person appointed by them. "The employer, says the law, will ensure that the amounts deducted are accounted separately from its own." He must keep them in trust. I ask you this: Does government use the money for its own purposes? Does government put it in a trust fund? Does government use it to reduce its deficit or the public debt? The Auditor General has already tabled a report in which he advised Parliament that the rate of return on the Public Service superannuation account was between 1 and 2 per cent under the current rate on the investment market. Pensions are not negotiable, Mr. Speaker. Therefore, there is a need to be fair to these employees in the legislation.
On the death of the contributor, the surviving spouse is entitled to 50 per cent of the benefits. Why is there no provision to allow surviving spouses, generally women, to receive 60 per cent, as provided for in other pension plans across the country? What government did with this 50 per cent entitlement is contrary to the terms of its own 1985 Pension Benefits Standards Act, which calls for 60 per cent. Is government truly committed to the well-being of its employees who, day after day, provide services and see to it that government legislation is enforced?
Why, discriminate against part-time employees, term employees, contract employees? It is unfair to women in particular. Why could part-time and term employees not contribute to the pension fund too? As you know, Public Service 2000 is now being implemented. This government's agenda is apparently to keep shrinking the Public Service indefinitely. It seems to have no respect for the Public Service and to want to privatize it all. Are we to understand that government is not really trying to provide its employees with a fair pension plan?
Then, there is this amendment about indexing. Why did the government vote against this amendment designed to maintain indexing? What is it up to? Does it have unpleasant surprises in store for its employees? Let us not forget that employees pay to get this protection. It is no gift or giveaway.

What does this government have against fairness? Why does it exempt itself from the standards established by the Pension Benefits Standards legislation? Why does it have to use regulations that leave distrust in the minds of public servants?
June 17, 1992

Government Orders
We are still not sure that these regulations would not be used to change the benefits received even from de-indexed pensions.
I would like to refer to Bill C-55, an act to amend certain acts in relation to pensions and to enact the Special Retirement Arrangements Act and the Pension Benefits Division Act. Subsection 80(3) says:
(3) In the event of any inconsistency between the provisions of any regulations made under subsection (1) or (2) and the provisions of this act or any other regulations made under this act, the provisions of the regulations made under subsection (1) or (2) prevail to the extent of the inconsistency.
Surely, the government could have done much better in making the Public Service pension regime fairer. It has lost an important opportunity to show the public that it values public servants' contribution to our country and that it believes in fairness and justice.
Why has this clause been put in? Is it for justice? I doubt it very much. Is this a new road we are taking in Parliament where it is not Parliament and the laws that are going to prevail but rather the regulations prepared by-

-senior officials who prepare the regulations for the ministers? I think that in future we can expect to have some serious problems in this country if we are governed by senior officials instead of by acts of Parliament.
The government blithely ignored the recommendations of witnesses who appeared before the Legislative Committee. Public servants are treated with contempt and ignored by this government. It has no respect for public servants, whose morale is very low. It is difficult to achieve professionalism. And of course, there is the government's tendency to favour contracting out. As in the private sector, public servants contribute their fair share to the pension fund, and they are entitled to it. They have made a lifetime investment. The government, the self-appointed sole trustee of the plan, must be fair and frank with its employees in every respect.

Mr. Speaker, I rise to address an aspect of this bill that I consider extremely important to the affairs of Parliament.
I suppose the area I am concerned with does not directly relate to the matter of pensions. The bill, as described here tonight, is almost an omnibus bill that directs its attention to a number of different types of amendments in pension legislation.
The area I want to highlight has already been referred to by other members here this evening, but I feel I have a very special interest in this area of the law of Parliament. It is an area I work in at the committee level for Parliament. I feel it is essential that the records of Parliament reflect my views, at least. I may be, along with a few other small voices, crying in the wilderness but there is a serious problem here and I want to describe it now.
In clauses 30 and 58 of this bill there are provisions that delegate to the Governor in Council, and therefore the bureaucracy, the right and power to make regulations. That happens in almost every bill we pass here.
It also says in both clauses:
In the event of any inconsistency between the provisions of any regulations made under subsection (1) or (2) and the provisions of this act or any other regulations made under this act, the provisions of the regulations made under subsection (1) or (2) prevail to the extent of the inconsistency.
That means that when this House passes this law it is at the same time giving the Governor in Council and the bureaucracy the right to make a regulation that is inconsistent with this act, that flies in the face of this act. This Parliament is stating that regulation will prevail over the law that is passed in this House.
I was shocked when I read that and I went to the effort of taking some legal counsel on the issue. I said that surely this House cannot delegate to someone outside of Parliament the right to pass laws and change the law of Parliament. The answer that I got was that it has been dealt with before in history a few times. It is in fact not

June 17, 1992
Government Orders
unconstitutional. The concept has been universally condemned and is regarded as a constitutional impropriety. I am telling this House now that the concept that it is about to adopt in this bill is regarded by constitutional experts in the western world as a constitutional impropriety.
What I as a member see it as is a situation where the government is continually chipping away at the rights and authority of this Parliament. At the very least, I must make reference to it.
I want to do it because I want to caution this House and Canadians to not take the current equilibrium of checks and balances, constitutional and political, as they exist in this country, for granted. It has been gained at a constitutional history cost over several hundred years beginning with the Magna Carta and going on through the Bill of Rights in the 1800s, the Bill of Rights in Canada under the British North America Act in 1867, the Bill of Rights in 1960, the Constitution Act and the Charter of Rights. Here we are in 1992 doing something that, as I have said, has been universally condemned. It was so condemned in the year 1930 when the Donough-more committee clearly stated on the record for the British Parliament whose system we have adopted here in the following words describing the situation: "It cannot but be regarded as inconsistent with the principles of parliamentary government that the subordinate law-making authority should be given the superior law-making authority power to amend a statute which has been passed by the superior authority".
That is fairly wordy, but what I want to ask here is: do members opposite realize that they are on behalf of their electors delegating to the bureaucracy and the Governor in Council the right to make a law that is inconsistent with the law we are passing here tonight? I do not think they know it. I want the record to show veiy clearly that when I vote against this bill, this is the principal reason I vote against it. To be sure, there are others, but this is the principal reason I vote against it.
This concept of delegating in this manner has not been seen in a previous statute to the best of my knowledge. There was one occasion in this House last year when in adopting the new copyright law this House in a provision in the statute stated that in implementing an international copyright convention the Governor in Council could
make changes to adapt to the international convention; the same principle, but at least tied to an international convention.
In this case there is no parameter, no limit, no guidance, no strictures, no measuring stick, but simply a statement that if the Governor in Council passes a regulation inconsistent with this act the regulation prevails. That is law-making overriding the law of Parliament by an Order in Council. That is a tyranny of the majority on the other side of this House because once given it will be bloody hard to get it back.
I have made reference to the previous constitutional history, what it has been called. My colleagues on this side of the House have already described it as a Henry VIII clause. The concept has been around for 400 years. It has been recognized as I have said as a constitutional impropriety. The only way the British Parliament managed to get rid of the Henry VIII clause was when the guy died. When Henry VIII died they removed the law that let the king make a proclamation that could override the rights and the law of Parliament.
This government is following in the same footsteps as Henry VIII. There is no other way to describe it. There are smiles around, Mr. Speaker. It sounds cute but it is very important. It is a very important principle. I cannot help but allude to the President of the Treasury Board as walking in the footsteps or wearing the mantle of or with the crown of Henry VIII. He might even do it well.
Let me put a scenario so that the record can show some of my real concerns. If there were an inadvertent conflict, inadvertent inconsistency, between the rights that will be passed under this statute and the statute itself, one could understand in some cases where you would want to settle the difference. I think it should be settled. The law of the land says that Parliament's law governs. That is what the law says now.
But what happens over time if the Public Service, the Governor in Council, says to heck with this, we have a provision that lets us make a regulation that overrides it. The member shakes his head, "not in your lifetime". We are talking 400 years of constitutional history here.
What if that happens? I am saying that Parliament has just given the government and the Governor in Council the right to make a law that overrides the law we cast in this House. They are incredulous over there. They do not believe that would really happen.
June 17, 1992

It is not going to happen tomorrow. I will take their word on that. We have seen it in this one statute, just this one. What happens if this fall we have another statute with the same provision, and another one next year, and the year after that, because the bureaucrats draft these bills; the minister does not. Soon we have dozens of statutes with the same kind of provision. What if there is a problem in this House some day, a constitutional problem? The government can simply decide to go right ahead and run this country by passing regulations that are inconsistent with the statutes because the concept has been accepted if we pass this bill here in June 1992. They will look back and say that it was okay in June 1992, it must be okay now in 1993, in 1994. That is a great danger. Trying to roll this stuff back is very difficult.
Just two years ago there were Standing Orders that governed procedures in this House. Those Standing Orders were significantly, materially, amended over the objections of the opposition. The reason they passed was because the government had a majority. That incident itself showed how the majority could override the rights of the minority in this House. We are not talking about passage of laws. We are talking about the Standing Orders that determine how Parliament works on a day-to-day basis.
The government that did it was insensitive to the issue. This section is a reflection of that same insensitivity, an insensitivity to the law of Parliament, an insensitivity to our constitutional history, and an insensitivity to what I referred to as the equilibrium of the checks and balances in our constitutional law.
I regret that this is going to be law within a few days or weeks. I want the record to show that and I object to it strongly.

I welcome the opportunity to present a few comments on this bill.
As you are aware, Mr. Speaker, the New Democrats are opposing this bill. There are, I would suggest, two main reasons why we oppose this bill and certainly two reasons why I am opposing this bill. The first reason has to do with the fact that for some time now superannuates at the FSNA have been calling for a joint management board to manage the funds of this pension plan.
Mr. Speaker, as you also will be well aware, there is something in the order of $75 billion or $80 billion sitting
Government Orders
in this account somewhere that is being managed solely by the Treasury Board and for some time the superannuates have been asking for some say in how this is being managed.
To be fair, there is an advisory board around, but I am of the understanding that this board has not been consulted for some five years. What they have been asking for is something that has some real power, a joint management board that would be made up of the government as employer, the employees, superannuates and of course a representative of a spouse, all of whom would actually manage those funds.
The Auditor General in his report this year said that this fund is losing something like a billion dollars a year in interest alone. It is losing that money because of the way the government has invested it. It is very difficult to get answers from the government. The government has been very, very hush-hush and very reluctant to make any comments with respect to investments, but certainly this $75 billion is not sitting in an account in the Bank of Montreal or a credit union somewhere. It has been borrowed by this government. In fact it is part of this $400 billion debt that exists in this country.
That is all very well and fine if in fact there was a joint management board that decided in its wisdom that it wanted to lend the government x millions or billions of dollars on certain terms, but to simply have the government investing and using this money as it sees fit with these promises leaves many superannuates unsure and in fact very frustrated. When you get a report such as the Auditor General's report saying that this account is losing a billion dollars a year in interest and you have the superannuates saying that they cannot find out exactly where these accounts are being invested, in what form and in what fashion and what the plan is for these accounts, it is very frustrating. The government refusing to set up that management board sets a very bad precedent in this country.
In my riding there are a lot of seniors who are CPR pensioners on CPR pension funds and they have a lot of concerns over what has happened with their account. There is a lot of secrecy concerning that fund. It would certainly be important for this government to take some lead in dealing with pension funds in this country. When this baby boom generation reaches retirement there is going to be a lot of need for those funds and by God there had better be some accounting for them and they had better be there and available. Therefore, the fact of a joint management board makes very good sense and

Government Orders
would certainly ensure that these pension funds are being spent and being used properly.
The other disappointing thing is that with the amount of interest and growth that is happening with this fund, I am led to believe that something like only one-half of the interest that is being accrued in this account goes to benefits. That means that the other half of the interest is being accrued to the account itself as well as the employer and employee benefits that are being paid into it. This is a huge fund that is growing at a huge rate. It is paying benefits to superannuates and their death benefits have not risen in I do not know how many years. They have been asking for an increase in death benefits and survival benefits, but this government has been very reluctant and in fact stonewalled them time after time.
The fact that the government has refused to put in this joint management board is one of the key reasons why I cannot support this bill. I know that it is something that pensioners have been calling for and the government has simply ignored them.
The other matter is this business of the regulatory authority that has been given to this government under this bill. I have watched in this House for the last four years and have seen this government show disrespect for this House time and time and time again.
I was involved in a bill called the At and East which had to do with grain being moved by rail cars to eastern Canada. It was announced that this subsidy would be cut in the 1989 budget and it was cut but the law was never changed.
I raised it in the House at the end February in 1990. Within two days the bill was introduced in the House. The government was violating its own law in total disregard for Parliament, in total disregard for this country-no debate in the House; make an announcement and the provision is gone. That is showing complete disrespect for this House, complete disrespect for this country and complete disrespect for Canadian citizens.
We have seen enabling legislation that has come forth and there is a place for enabling legislation. This government has used it time and again to meet its own purposes.
I was involved in the debate on GRIP and we had this enabling legislation in front of us. We never did see the program and we were not getting details that the government knew were going to be in the program. The government pushed the bill through and then implemented the program.
Under the gun control legislation huge control has been given to the minister and to the Cabinet with respect to regulations in areas in which they can make changes to the bill via the regulations. Very important areas in all propriety should be dealt with by this House. The government has again ignored the House.
I never thought I would see the day when the government would put this section in this bill. Others have raised it. It is unbelievable and I am going to read it again into the record. It is amazing. Clause 80(3) says: "In the event of any inconsistency between the provisions of any regulations made under subsection (1) or (2) of the provisions of this act or any other regulations made under this act, the provisions of the regulations made under subsection (1) or (2) prevail to the extent of the inconsistency".
In other words, regulations can be made by the Cabinet that are contrary to statutes that this House passes.
I am not sure why we are debating a bill. We are debating a bill here that presumably is going to put into law certain legislation regarding pensions. The government can turn around at its will and through the Cabinet make changes to the regulations. If they are contrary to this statute it does not matter and they will not be debated in this House. That is unbelievable. It is actually unbelievable.
What the hell am I doing here on this bill? If this is what Parliament is coming to we should let the Governor General hold little councils somewhere and pass rules, send us out a letter and let us know what the law is. That is what this amounts to.
It is an insult. It is an insult to every member in the House and it is an insult to every Canadian in this country that this type of garbage is going into legislation and yet the government is doing it. It is very upsetting.

I have a lot of seniors in my riding who have been following this bill quite closely. It is amazing, it is dumbfounding, it is a shock. This bill should not be supported. It should be voted against by every single member of this House.
I want to close if I could by making some comments on MPs' pensions. I have gone on record as saying MPs' pensions should be reviewed.
It is very important the way that our leader has handled this area of the bill, calling for an independent inquiry. The government has agreed to at some point set up an independent committee, independent of this House and of the Senate, to review MPs' pensions. That is what our leader called for, that is what we have been calling for. That is appropriate.
I am a new member in this House. I have not reached my pensionable age and I certainly think it is appropriate that there be some changes. If I had the opportunity to be here long enough I would receive a pension at a relatively young age. Certainly it would be appropriate to have an independent committee make binding recommendations to this House that should be implemented with respect to MPs' pensions.
It is important and I only hope that the government sets that committee up soon. There is no date for this committee, it is somewhere in the future. I do hope that the government will get that committee up and running very soon.
In closing, certainly I cannot support this bill nor can any of my party colleagues support it. I would be surprised at any member in the House who could stand up in full honesty and support this bill.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to make some comments with respect to the hon. member's speech. I congratulate him, especially on his last comments on the pensions of members of Parliament. I agree that we have to look at it. We should be careful of the National Citizens Coalition. It has a different agenda. It wants to raise money for its own right wing causes and it will do it on the back of this issue. MPs would be wise not to give it the issue to ride. As I understand it, the House is proceeding to an
Government Orders
independent committee outside the House on the suggestion of the leader of my party. I am pleased with that.
I wanted to comment about pensions in general. I had raised this before with the hon. member for New Westminster-Burnaby when she spoke and I raised it with my hon. friend who just spoke. These things are very intertwined; the Canada Pension, the notion of divorced and widowed women concerning pensions and the difficulties that arise.
My concern is that we have not really dealt with a lot of things in this bill when we had the chance. I found the letter I was referring to before and I want to read it and get my friend to comment.
"I am a single mom, widowed since 1977. This year my son, who is 18 now-six feet, six inches and 250 pounds- is out of school and not yet able to find work. He is now disqualified from both family allowance payments and orphans' benefits. I still have to feed him", and at that size you can imagine he eats a lot, "but I have to do so on $150 less a month than I did in January.
I did receive an increase in my Canada Pension in January but because it was directly deposited I have no idea why. speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to add my few words to this debate on Bill C-55 and speak to some very specific provisions in response to representations which I received from numerous constituents concerning this legislation.
Most constituents are concerned with one thing. They see this bill as a serious threat to their indexed pensions. My constituents are worried and confused about what is in the bill. Although it is thick and complex, they all recognize that it is an obvious attempt by this government to bury its attack on indexation deep within the bill, hoping that no one will notice.
Everyone has noticed, Mr. Speaker; civil servants, the armed forces, and veterans. They have all noticed what this government is doing and they are not going to let it get away with it.
The bill amends four pension acts, public servants, Canadian forces, RCMP, and members of Parliament. This bill could very well be several bills and by all rights should have been separated.
The most controversial element of the bill falls on page 32. It is here that clause 71(3) states that should any of the regulations made under this bill conflict with the act itself that the regulations would prevail.
That is exactly what has caused all the concern. This clause leaves the door open for the government to
Government Orders
sneakily enact a regulation affecting indexation, thereby avoiding having to go to Parliament with it.
I know well how much this government hates going to Parliament. The fisheries minister has avoided Parliament for over a year now with his individual transferable quotas and his dockside monitoring program.
Pensioners across the country protested and groups which appeared before the legislative committee spelled out their concerns.
At first the Treasury Board president dismissed these concerns as irrelevant and unfounded but he finally gave in and proposed an amendment in committee. Its text is on page 34, clause 71(5). It protects against a reduction in benefits at the hands of any regulation but it only offers protection for benefits which have accrued before the day on which the regulation is made. Any and all future benefits are unprotected and up for grabs.
Keith Pickering is a constituent of mine from Inverness. He is an armed forces retiree with over 21 years of service in Canada. I would like to quote a section of his letter to me:
We believed the government, our employer, would look after our
pension fund the same as they looked after their own pension fund. I
find out now that the government does not really care about their
employees or their welfare, as Bill C-55 has shown.
Mr. Pickering and other armed forces retirees recognize that there are some good things in the bill for them such as increasing the supplementary death benefits for armed forces' survivors. But these good things pale in comparison to the potential for disaster should indexation be left vulnerable.
These positive elements in the bill also include pension splitting, coverage for part-time workers, and early retirement for correctional services employees. Because these are long overdue, their presence in Bill C-55 makes it more difficult to oppose the bill as a whole. Their presence pits pensioner against pensioner and is, I believe, all part of the government's "divide and conquer" mentality.
Another constituent called yesterday morning concerned about the pension splitting provisions of the bill. She is worried that this element of the bill will not come into effect in time to help her. She and thousands of other Canadians have been waiting for years for this government to act on this issue. This government has coupled in this bill positive provisions like pension splitting with something as dangerously wrong as dein-

Government Orders
dexation. This is cheating Canadians. It plays political games with their security and livelihood.
All Canadians are realizing that Bill C-55 is just a sneakier version of Bill C-33 in 1985. The government has not learned from its mistake. Indeed, it is pushing ahead with its deindexation agenda despite figures like the following examples: The 1989 poverty line for one person was just over $1,100 per month and for two people, just over $1,500 per month; in 1989 pension amounts were indexed pensions, just over $1,000; unindexed pensions, just over $700. For surviving spouses the amounts are dreadfully less. Indexation is fundamental to people's livelihood following retirement, and these figures clearly illustrate that.
The population of Canada is quickly aging with fewer young people entering the labour force to support them. It provides a real social dilemma and pension reform is long overdue. This is what is necessary and the government can no longer continue to avoid it.

The House resumed consideration of Bill C-26, an act to amend the Public Service Employment Act, the Public Service Staff Relations Act and other acts in relation to the Public Service of Canada, as reported (with amendments) from a legislative committee; and on Motions Nos. 1 and 3 (p. 12268).

Mr. Speaker, these two motions quite properly have been grouped because they are changes to definitions in the act that are very much related one to the other.
Government Orders
One of the major changes in this bill is a move away from the long-standing principle, long-standing to the tune of 70 years since the first Civil Service Act was passed by this Parliament, that the person best qualified for a job gets the job. We will be discussing that particular aspect of this bill in several clauses throughout the bill to demonstrate that is, in fact, the case.
One of the fundamental changes that happens here is that people can now be deployed. Up until now, people have been appointed in the Public Service. That means they are hired into a position for the first time, they are promoted to another position, or they move to another position. In all cases whether they are or are not appointed is based on some method for determining who is the best qualified among those who want that position.
In Bill C-26, we now have a thing called deployment. Members of Parliament may remember over a year ago changes were made, not through legislation but through Orders in Council, that people could be transferred from one position to another without the right of appeal and without any reference to the Public Service Employment Act which for many years has ensured we have a Public Service that is fairly and impartially appointed.
The ability to transfer people without paying any attention to the act that has protected those principles for seven decades was challenged in court. It was thrown out by the courts because the court said very clearly the ability to transfer people was contrary to the merit principle.
With that court decision in hand, the government in this bill is now trying to make legal what the courts have thrown out. The bill says that somebody may be deployed, i.e., transferred from one position to another. Again, the bill very clearly spells out that those deployments have to pay no attention whatsoever to merit or to bilingualism. They are unappealable and an employee who feels unjustly treated has no recourse against the deployment. It is totally within the arbitrary discretion of a manager.
Unfortunately, what the provisions of the act also do is allow deployments to be used for promotions. That is clearly contrary to the merit principle where people move up in the Public Service according to ability, not according to whether the manager likes them or not.

June 17, 1992
Government Orders
The distinction between a lateral transfer and a promotion becomes blurred in this legislation. What I have attempted to do with these motions is to get rid of that blurring.
Deployments will now be able to be made within very broad categories with very broad salary ranges and with no accountability. The government will group employees, in one case in groups of up to 110,000 employees, obviously with very many salary levels, very many layers of responsibility and a manager is free to move somebody up that scale or down that scale without any reference to the requirements of the act and without any appeal.
These two motions attempt to clearly define what is a deployment i.e., a lateral transfer, and what is a promotion. The bill now says simply that a deployment is the movement of an employee from one position to another. The government has tried to persuade us that these are not promotions or demotions but simply sideways moves. They are not.
What I have done in Motion No. 1 is to clearly specify that a deployment is at the same level of responsibility and that the person has already qualified on merit to be transferred within that level of responsibility. I have used the precise words the commission gave to the legislative committee in describing what a deployment was going to be used for.
I have difficulty understanding why the government would not accept this amendment to clarify that deployments will not be used as a guise for promotions or demotions. In other words, any movement within the Public Service could become a deployment that is unaccountable and unappealable.
For the same reason, promotion is defined. In the legislation a promotion will from henceforth, if the legislation stays unamended, mean whatever the commission says it means. That is quite simply what the legislation says. A promotion is as defined in the regulations of the commission.
Employees will no longer have a clear definition of what is a promotion, where somebody was improperly awarded without going through competition, and therefore they will have no grounds on which to appeal a promotion they think was unjustly made.
Putting in these amendments is only one small part of what is necessary to ensure that there is still some accountability, still some attention to fair hiring and promotion practices in the Public Service but they are a starting point.
They put words on what the government has said it means in this legislation, on what the Public Service Commission says deployment will be used for. Since we have these motions out for debate, I look forward to hearing why the government does not want to accept, if it does not want to accept, wording that reflects what it says are its stated intentions.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to congratulate my colleague on the motions she presented. The important point here concerns the definition of what a promotion is, but the issue is the merit principle.
Will public servants really be able to have confidence in a future where their promotions and working life will be regulated fairly and equitably, with clear definitions of what is meant by promotion, transfer and demotion? To whom will they appeal? That is the big question. I can well understand that the minister wants to give managers more power so that decisions can be made much more quickly.
However, I do not think that he put in place the mechanisms needed to protect public servants who might be abused by some managers. Generally speaking, we know that managers and senior officials are conscientious and think of serving the Canadian public in the best possible way and are very honest.
Nevertheless, it would be very difficult to correct any abuses that may occur. A senior official might have racial prejudices or prefer men over women or vice versa. It would be rather difficult if he discriminated discreetly, not to say hypocritically, by forming teams from his old boys' network around him. He could surround himself with his friends and relatives and like-minded people and keep others out of his circle. He would have the power to transfer some employees outside or inside his section or service and these employees would not be subject to competitions to determine the best candidate for promotion.
June 17, 1992

We know very well that the number of public service occupational categories will be greatly reduced, from 75 now to possibly 24 or 25. This means that in general, for every three categories now there would be only one.
Say that someone works in category 1, the lowest level, and an employer or senior official wants to transfer him. He could easily move from level 1 to level 3. Who could appeal? Who could discuss the good and bad points of this transfer? There will be various gradations between level 1 and level 3, between level 4 and level 6 and between level 7 and level 9. Managers will be able to transfer employees as they like and also, unfortunately, according to their prejudices.
So the important point to keep in mind is that with a quarter of a million employees, there must be transfers, promotions and even demotions and it is very important to have mechanisms so that employees who feel wronged, overlooked, mistreated or discriminated against in the decision can appeal.
It is true that appeals can now take a long time. I would have preferred the minister to deal with the length of appeals instead of reducing the opportunity to appeal.
So, Mr. Speaker, with great regret, having participated in many meetings of the legislative committee that studied the new public service bill, I realized that the merit principle will no longer exist in the Public Service of Canada, one of the best, if not the best, public service in the world.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to very briefly concur with the words spoken by my two colleagues from Ottawa West and Carleton- Gloucester.
The essence of these motions is to try to address one of the fundamental concerns that we have about Bill C-26 and the amendments that it brings about to the management of the Public Service system in Canada. These changes undermine the principle that promotion and appointment are based on the principle of merit, first and foremost.
This principle, which has been the bedrock of the Public Service management over the last number of
Government Orders
decades in Canada, is fundamental to having the kind of capable, competent, independent and non-partisan Public Service that Canadians have the right to expect and require.
In particular, the merit principle manages to eliminate the political patronage that at one time characterized appointments to the Public Service and also is the method of ensuring that bureaucratic patronage, which in some ways is even more insidious and more difficult to deal with than political patronage, does not become the order of the day in making appointments or promotions.
It is crucial that we in the House of Commons restate again the importance we place on this principle and the concern we have that this legislation is likely to undermine it.
As an example of the criticisms that we have, allow me to quote from Hugh Winsor's commentary that appeared on May 23 in The Globe and Mail. He wrote: "Civil service managers would also be given leeway to redeploy people within categories without competitions, something the Treasury Board attempted to do under the existing Public Service Employment Act and was rapped on the knuckles for it by a federal court judge. The Public Service Commission has delegated much of the responsibility for hiring to the deputy ministers in individual departments and admitted in its most recent annual report there has been too much abuse of the system. Too many deputy ministers and assistant deputy ministers are appointing their cronies and redeploying people they do not like or putting people in allegedly temporary acting positions without going through the competition process, the commission said".
This is really what we are trying to get at here. We are not saying that the Public Service administration needs to be burdened down with red tape and bureaucracy or that managers should be hamstrung in their ability to manage, none of that is appropriate to these criticisms.
It is crucial that the integrity of the merit principle be preserved, not only for the benefit of the people who labour daily within the Public Service and have hope of promotion and career advancement but also for the benefit of the people of Canada who deserve to be served by a Public Service that continues to understand and implement this principle of meritorious reward for effort.

June 17, 1992
Government Orders

Mr. Speaker, as I rise to take part in this debate I find what I see taking place here very disturbing.
The other members who spoke discussed promotion on the merit principle. What we are also seeing happen is a loss of morale within the Public Service. There are people in CEIC centres and other places telling the unemployed: "Don't bother to come here, there are no jobs. We cannot find you any jobs".
Prior to these changes, and the proposed changes in this bill, the people in these centres would go out of their way, they would go that extra mile, to try to help the unemployed. This is lowering the morale of these people. They do not know where they are going to be. They do not know that if they do their job well they are going to be the people who are selected for promotion.
I am scared at what I see happening here, because we are taking this away. This is something where the Public Service says yes, there have been a lot of problems with it over the years. There has been quite a bureaucratic nightmare in a lot of cases. I hesitate to warn the government that we cannot change these things this drastically, to give this power to managers and just to throw out the merit principle. I find this bothers me and I know it bothers the Public Service of this country. It certainly bothers the public of this country because you have people coming to you. You know the old saying: "If you don't know somebody, you are not going to get that promotion". This is an area that certainly the public is very concerned about. I am sure that if we allow this amendment that has been put forward, it will make this bill that much more palatable.

I did not have the benefit of hearing all of the speech of the hon. member for Carleton-Gloucester, so I was not able to say that he dwelt on quite the same terrors that were outlined by the other members in relation to what would happen with this bill if it is passed in its existing form. The President of the Treasury Board, who has a significant responsibility for the Public Service in this country, should know better than to introduce a bill such as this with this kind of change in the House.
I know what is going on and I think the public of Canada knows what is going on. It is a power grab by senior public servants. The minister is being used as their tool for the purpose of getting this power grab. They are taking over the question of promotion and transfer in the Public Service in a way as well as demotion-promotion, demotion and transfer in the Public Service-in a way that is totally unprecedented in our system. Ultimately the responsibility for that is going to fall on the minister's head, so that when an incompetent gets shifted or moved into a higher position without competition in the face of-
The Peter principle.

No, no, no. The hon. member for Hillsborough would not want to call it the Peter principle. If someone of lesser competence gets transferred to a position for which there were better applicants, there is going to be a problem. It is going to create problems for ministers. It is going to create problems for deputy ministers and worse, it is going to create problems for the public of Canada who have reason to expect a reasonable level of service from their Public Service.
What this bill is doing is taking away any sense of responsibility for these appointments from the independent Public Service Commission. Far be it from me to stand here today to defend the Public Service Commission. I have moved amendments to this bill which we will be discussing another day that would restrict its powers. In my view it has not shown itself to be responsive to the wishes of Parliament to which it is responsible. The hon. member for Burlington perhaps disagrees. If so, I invite him to rise and make a speech. I would be glad to hear from him on this subject.
June 17, 1992

I think generally the Public Service Commission has not been responsive to Parliament to which it is responsible. It is not responsible to the government. It is responsible to this Parliament, this House and the other place. In my submission, based on past evidence that I have seen, it has been very unresponsive to the demands of this House. As a result, I introduced a private member's bill which would have brought it to heel. It would have created for it in the statute things that it should have done by regulation as recommended by a joint committee of the Senate and the House of Commons and which report it ignored. Many of the amendments that I have proposed to BUI C-26 are based on that refusal or ignorance, if you wish to call it that, on the part of the Public Service Commission to deal with amendments that I put forward.
The hon. member for Scarborough-Rouge River is on the committee that has studied this again and has made a report simUar to the one originally proposed by the predecessor committee in I believe 1987. That report was ignored by the Public Service Commission.
I have no particular desire to stand here today and defend that commission. What I do defend very vigorously is the importance of the independence of the Public Service and the importance of a lack of political interference in the promotion, transfer and demotion process in the Public Service.
If the merit principle is removed, what is replacing it? That is the question that is not answered by this legislation. A blanket power is given to promote, demote or transfer without regard to merit. If merit is taken out, what is the regard for? What is the promotion, demotion or transfer to be based on? The minister's whim? Surely the President of the Treasury Board does not want to have to take personal responsibUity for every transfer, promotion or demotion in the Public Service of Canada.
I suspect you are right.

He says he suspects I am right. Then let us fix this bUl so that the minister does not have to take that responsibUity. Let us make an objective judgment that somebody can look at.
I know the minister perhaps would prefer a subjective judgment but his answer indicated he would not.
Government Orders
Let us have an objective measure by which promotions, demotions and transfers can be judged and let us base it on the merit principle. What could be simpler than that? It has worked for us in the past. It can continue to work for us.
What the hon. member for Ottawa West has proposed is that clause 2 of the bUl be amended so that deployment means the transfer of an employee from one position to another position at the same level of responsibUity for which the employee has already been qualified by the commission. In other words, it can only be a lateral transfer if it is a deployment. It cannot be a demotion and it cannot be a promotion.
Second, on the term promotion, which is left wide open in the minister's bUl-the minister points his finger at me-let me read his definition to him. I find it hard to believe a minister with the intelligence and the abUity of the President of the Treasury Board would propose such a ridiculous bUl to the House; a distinguished man. The Minister of Justice sitting beside him is a well educated individual as well. One would have thought she might have read this bUl and said, "We cannot have this. As a government we could not introduce anything so sUly". She sits sUent in her seat. I do not think she has spoken yet on this bUl. I would have thought she might.
Promotion says the bUl "has the meaning assigned by the regulations of the commission". Thlk about a carte blanche for the commission. The commission can do whatever it wants. It does not listen to Parliament. We have evidence of that already.
What the hon. member for Ottawa West proposed is that promotion means the movement of an employee from one position to another position at a higher level of responsibUity or at a higher maximum rate of pay than the level of responsibUity or the maximum rate of pay of the position the employee previously occupied. What is wrong with that definition?
I say to the President of the Treasury Board, come back to the House and tell us what is wrong. Never mind running for comfort to the Chair. Come and speak in the House and tell us what is wrong with this bUl. This amendment makes sense. This amendment is reasonable. This amendment upholds the principles on which the Public Service has functioned lo these many, many, many years.

June 17, 1992
Government Orders
The hon. member for Burlington probably cannot even remember when it was different. Certainly I cannot. I am sure the youthful member for Ottawa West cannot.
The hon. member is sounding as though he is a violin. I am sorry he feels that way about this speech. Perhaps he has heard it all before. If so, surely he should change his tune and get up and object to this bill.
If he had objected in caucus, if the hon. member for Burlington had raised this issue in caucus, he might have got somewhere with this bill. As it is, it is left to us in opposition in this House to publicly condemn the government for its action in proposing this kind of amendment in the House.
I see the hon. member for Cambridge getting into the act as well. He must know this is wrong. He has heard my
very reasonable arguments. Perhaps the President of the Treasury Board is getting some advice as to whether this amendment should not be accepted and if it could be done without defeating the government.
Certainly we would not regard it as a question of confidence if this amendment were to carry tonight, Mr. Speaker, and I invite you to put the question to the House.
